title: Mount Buggery (Alpine Shire, Victoria)
text:
Mount Buggery is a mountain located in the <a href="Alpine%20Shire">Alpine Shire</a> within the <a href="Alpine%20National%20Park">Alpine National Park</a> in the <a href="Victorian%20Alps">alpine</a> region of <a href="Victoria%20%28Australia%29">Victoria</a>, <a href="Australia">Australia</a>. The mountain is located on the end of a ridgeline known as the Crosscut Saw between Mount Speculation and <a href="Mount%20Howitt">Mount Howitt</a>, both located to the south of Mount Buggery.
The summit of Mount Buggery rises in the range of <a href="Australian%20Height%20Datum">above sea level</a>.
Etymology.
There is circumstantial evidence that the mountain was named by a member of the Melbourne Walking Club who, during 1934, hiked along the <a href="Buckland%20River%20%28Victoria%29">Buckland</a><a href="Buffalo%20River%20%28Victoria%29">Buffalo</a> <a href="drainage%20basin">watershed</a> to <a href="Mount%20Selwyn%20%28mountain%29">Mount Selwyn</a>, and then on to the Barry Mountains to Mount Speculation, followed the Crosscut Saw to Mount Howitt, and finished at Merrijig via the <a href="Howqua%20River">Howqua River</a>. Other members of the hiking party and within the Melbourne Walking Club started using the name, and it eventually appeared on maps; official acceptance followed.
